div.note:
From Brewster (ed.), Edinburgh Encyclopaedia, vol. 18, p. 281.
The Encyclopaedia quotes Gibbon, Decline and Fall, vol. 5, chapter LI: Conquests by the Arabs, Part VII, and chapter LII: More Conquests by the Arabs, parts I and III.
'640 mosques' confirms that WG was reading the Encyclopaedia, as Gibbon gives 600.

القنطرهthe arch Alcantara from bridge. 2 Spanish orders with arab names. Fontarabia from [Arabic]
Almogavares from غارraid gar = pillage.

Almogavares of Granada = peons labradores y hombres del Campo. 3 Knights with 2 of these in Las antiguidades de la ciuidas de España 1775 mentions these as distinguished'labradores y hombres del Campo': peasant farmers and country men.
[Ambrosio de Morales], Las antiguedades de las ciudades de España (Alcalá de Henares, 1575), fo. 127v (foliated, not paginated). [The antiquities of the cities of Spain; not 1775]
Morales does not reproduce Arabic script, though, so cannot be source for what comes before. In fact, WG likely to be reading about Morales through another source, perhaps with same error on publication date.
Adalides Or champions, military leadersالدليلguides = guides. Almocadems المقدمchief chief. in armies. King only named these.
An Adalid had a dress, a sword, a horse & 2 armours. a rich man girded on his sword & he was hoisted on his shield. He drew his sword & turning defied the enemies of his King.
Thus an Adalid was a Knight or like one.

A KtKnight or Rico ombreNobleman (the common Spanish term; literally, 'rich man') had coat of arms & a Banner. If an Adalid was taken by Enemy the state ransomed them & had them cruelly killed. yet the honour sought by Knights.
